english_translation: Narrated by Abu Saeed al-Khudri: A man placed his hand on the Prophet ﷺ and said: 'By Allah, I cannot place my hand on you due to the severity of your fever.' The Prophet ﷺ said: 'We, the group of Prophets, have our trials multiplied for us just as our rewards are multiplied. Indeed if a Prophet from the Prophets was tested with poverty until the worn-out garment became his clothing, and they were to rejoice in trials as you rejoice in comfort.'

english_translation: Narrated by Hisham ibn Urwah from a worker of Adhraat: Umar ibn al-Khattab came to us with a shirt made of coarse linen. He gave it to me and said: 'Wash it and patch it.' I washed and patched it, then I cut for him a fine Egyptian shirt. I came to him with both of them together and said: 'This is your shirt and this is a shirt I cut for it so you may wear it.' He touched it with his hand and found it soft, so he said: 'We have no need for it. This (the original) absorbs the sweat better than this.'

english_translation: Narrated from Hisham ibn Urwah from his father: Umar came to Syria and was met by the great leaders of the people and the commanders of the troops. Umar said: 'Where is my brother?' They said: 'Who?' He said: 'Abu Ubaidah.' They said: 'He is coming to you now.' He came on a camel with a rope bridle, and he greeted him and spoke with him. Then he said to the people: 'Leave us alone.' He walked with him until they came to his house. He came down at his house and found nothing in it except his sword, his shield, and his saddle. Umar said to him: 'If you had taken some possessions.' Or he said: 'Something.' Abu Ubaidah said: 'O Commander of the Faithful! This will suffice to take us to the meeting place (with Allah).'

english_translation: Narrated by Yahya ibn Abi Kathir from a man of the people of Syria: I entered upon Abu Dharr while he was igniting wood beneath a pot that had been rained upon, and his tears were flowing. His wife said to him: 'You had an alternative to this, if you had wished you would have been helped.' Abu Dharr said: 'This is my livelihood, so if you are pleased then well, otherwise under the shelter of Allah.' The narrator said: 'It was as if he had placed a stone in her mouth.' When what was in the pot had cooked, he brought a bowl for himself, broke into it a thick loaf of bread of his, then he brought what was in the pot and poured it over it, then he brought it to his wife, then he said to me: 'Come near.' We ate, then he ordered his slave-girl to give us drink so she gave us a drink of some goat's milk of his. I said: 'O Abu Dharr, if you had taken something for yourself in your house.' He said: 'O slave of Allah! Do you desire for me more reckoning than this? Is there not here a mat that we spread, and a cloak that we spread, and a garment that we wear, and a cooking pot that we cook in, and a bowl that we eat from, and in which we wash our heads, and a cup that we drink from, and a skin in which there is oil or fat, and a flour container in which there is flour? Do you desire more reckoning for me than this?' I said: 'Then where is your salary of four hundred dinars? And you are in honor from the salary, so where does it go?' He said: 'I will not hide it from you. For me in this village there are thirty horses. When my salary comes out I buy fodder for them, and provisions for those who take care of them, and expenses for my family. If anything remains from it I buy with it coins and place it with a Nabatean here. If my family needs the meat of a sheep they take from it, and if they need anything they take from it. Then I ride on them in the way of Allah. This is the path of my salary. There is with Abu Dharr neither a dinar nor a dirham.'

english_translation: Narrated by al-Zuhri from Hamzah ibn Abdullah ibn Umar: If much food was with Abdullah ibn Umar he would not be satisfied after eating once he found food. It is said that Ibn Mu'ti' visited him while he was ill and saw that his body had wasted away. He said to Safiyyah (Abdullah's wife): 'Why do you not treat him kindly so that perhaps his body will return to him? Prepare food for him.' She said: 'We do that, but he does not leave anyone from his family nor anyone present except he calls upon him (invokes something upon him). You speak to him about this.' Ibn Mu'ti' said to him: 'O Abu Abdillah al-Rahman! If you took food that would return your body to you.' He replied: 'Indeed, eight years have passed over me in which I did not have a single full meal, or he said: I did not have except one meal in them. So now you want me to be satisfied when there remains of my life only the thirst of a donkey.'
